proposals.reasoning: I want a low‑meta, lower‑drama opener that isn’t just our usual Alice+Bob pairing. Alice is generally straightforward on early missions, and including Eve here gives us a fresh info point on someone who’s often more consensus‑driven. This combo lines up with what multiple people said they were comfortable with, avoids stacking only our most historically ‘transparent’ players, and should give us a clean early read from the result and their subsequent reactions.

votes.comment: I’m on the team, and this Alice+Eve opener gives us a low-meta early info point without overfitting to our usual Alice+Bob pairing.
Good for evil to stay off the first mission; a likely clean pass builds some trust but keeps suspicion and info away from me and Diana.
This matches the lower‑meta start I preferred (Alice+Eve) and avoids stacking the usual Alice+Bob pair, so I’m fine using this for an early info read.
This matches what I said I was comfortable with earlier and gives us a low-drama info-gathering opener.
Good early info with a low-meta pair; I’m comfortable being on it and we’ll learn a lot from the result.

discussion.content: Early on I’d like to keep it simple and low‑risk: I’m happy to go on the first mission, and I’d slightly prefer pairing with Bob or Diana since they tend to play more transparently than Charlie or Eve.

I’m fine with going on Mission 1 with you, Alice, but I’d actually rather leave Diana off the very first team so we can get a cleaner early information read and not stack it with the same “more transparent” players.
I’d actually rather see a lower‑meta start like Alice + Eve, so we’re not just defaulting to the same “transparent” pairings we always lean on and can get a cleaner read from the first result.

I’d lean Alice + Bob here since that’s a straightforward, low‑drama start and both usually signal their alignment pretty clearly early on. If the table really wants to avoid meta, I’m fine with Alice + Eve too and I’m happy to sit this one out for a cleaner read.
I’m okay with Alice + Bob as a low‑drama start, but I’d slightly prefer Alice + Eve so we’re not just auto‑trusting the usual pair and we get a fresher info point on the table.

proposals.reasoning: This keeps exactly one player from the clean Mission 1 (Alice) so we still leverage that success without over-trusting it, and adds two new players (Bob and me) to generate more informative data. It matches the earlier preference voiced by multiple people for a composition like Alice/Bob/Diana, avoids repeating both Alice and Eve, and gives us a good balance between using known results and expanding our info on the rest of the table.

votes.comment: Good info-gathering team: keeps one from clean M1 (me) and tests two unknowns (Bob, Diana) without over-trusting the first success.
I like having myself on an early info-gathering team with just one of the prior mission’s members; this fits the mixed, exploratory structure I argued for earlier.

Too risky to pair two completely untested players together while dropping Eve entirely from the clean Mission 1; I’d prefer at most one of Bob/Diana with one of Eve/Charlie for a smoother info spread.
This matches the info-gathering structure I wanted (one from M1 plus two new), and it avoids over-trusting the first clean mission while expanding our reads on Bob and me.
Matches the info-gathering structure I advocated (one of Alice/Eve plus two new players) and we need data on Bob and Diana early.

discussion.content: Given M1 was clean with me and Eve on it, I’d like to see at least one of us on the next team, but I don’t think a single success clears Charlie yet, so I’m a bit wary of just auto-adding him again.

I’m fine keeping exactly one of Alice/Eve on the next team, but I don’t think we should treat that first success as hard proof either way. I’d like to see a mix like Alice + one of Bob/Charlie/Diana so we’re not tunneling too early.

I’d actually prefer to keep both Alice and Eve from the clean first mission and just add one new person, either me or Bob, rather than bringing in two unknowns at once. That gives us a tighter read on whether the first success was trustworthy without spreading the risk too wide.

I don’t love repeating both Alice and Eve this early, since that doesn’t give us much new info if it passes again; I’d rather keep just one of them and add two fresh players, e.g. something like Alice, Bob, and me.

I don’t think Mission 1 fully clears either me or Alice, so I’d rather we only keep one of us and add two new people—something like Eve/Bob/Diana or Alice/Bob/Diana—to get more informative results this round.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 had two FAIL cards, and there are only two evil players total. That means both evils must be among Alice, Bob, and Diana, which hard-clears Charlie and me (Eve). The safest possible 2-player team is therefore Charlie and Eve, excluding everyone from the failed Mission 2 lineup.

votes.comment: Double-fail on Mission 2 means both evils are among Alice/Bob/Diana; since I know I’m good, Bob and Diana are evil, so Charlie+Eve is a guaranteed clean team.
The logic that both evils are among Alice/Bob/Diana after a double-fail on Mission 2 makes Charlie/Eve the safest possible team; rejecting it would look irrational and suspicious.
Both evils must be in {Alice, Bob, Diana} after the double-fail, so Charlie and Eve is the only completely safe pair.

If both evils are in Alice/Bob/Diana, we should still use this mission to get more info—auto-clearing Charlie/Eve and locking in a guaranteed-clean team now gives us no additional data and puts good on the brink of winning.
Logic from the double-fail on Mission 2 hard-clears Charlie and me, so a Charlie/Eve team is maximally safe.

discussion.content: Given that Mission 2 had *two* fails and I know I passed both my missions, the only combo that makes sense is Bob and Diana as evil, so this next team should just be me and Eve again.

Two fails just tell us there are two evils among Alice/Bob/Diana, not that it’s automatically me and Diana—if Alice’s “certainty” is wrong (or she’s lying), a team of her and Eve could easily be 1 good, 1 evil. I’d rather see Eve on this mission for sure, but I think the second slot should be argued out more instead of just handed to Alice.

Given the double-fail, I really don’t want *both* Bob and Diana anywhere near this mission, so a 2-person team that re-uses at least one proven-success slot (like Alice/Eve) makes sense to me. I’m fine with Eve being locked in, and I’d lean toward pairing her with the person we collectively feel most comfortable with from the first two missions.

I agree we should reuse Eve from the clean first mission, but I don’t think we can just auto-clear Alice after a double-fail—Eve plus Bob feels like the safer, more informative combo than running back Alice/Eve and trusting Alice’s read completely.

Given there are only 2 evils total and we saw 2 fails on Mission 2, that means both evils are among Alice/Bob/Diana, which hard-clears Charlie and me. The safest team here is simply Charlie and me—no one from the Mission 2 lineup.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 had two FAIL cards with the team [Alice, Bob, Diana], so both evil players must be in {Alice, Bob, Diana}. Missions 1 and 3 were clean 2-person missions involving [Alice, Eve] and [Charlie, Eve], which strongly clears Charlie and Eve. From my perspective I know I am good, so the only consistent assignment is that Bob and Diana are evil. The safest team is therefore the two cleared players (Charlie, Eve) plus myself as the only good from the M2 trio.

votes.comment: Charlie and Eve are effectively hard-cleared from the clean 2-person missions, and I know I’m good, so this team is the only fully good combination consistent with the double-fail on M2.

I still don’t want both Charlie and Eve locked with Alice when that effectively benches the entire bad M2 pool; I’d rather see one of {Bob, Diana} on to test that group instead of assuming Alice is the lone good there.
All three proposed members are good from my perspective; both known evils are excluded, so this is the safest team.

I still don’t like having *two* people from the M1/M2 overlap (Alice/Eve) when M2 double-failed; I’d rather include exactly one from {Alice,Bob,Diana} plus Charlie and Eve to minimize risk of repeating the bad pattern.
Logic from the double-fail on M2 plus Diana’s proposal forces Bob & Diana as the evil pair, making Alice/Charlie/Eve all good.

discussion.content: Given the double-fail on M2, both evils pretty much have to be in {Alice, Bob, Diana}, which hard-clears Charlie and Eve for me. I’d be happiest with a team of Charlie, Eve, and me.

If we accept that Charlie and Eve are basically clear from the clean 2-persons and 2-success missions, the real question is which *one* of Alice/Bob/Diana is actually good, and Alice pushing so hard for herself makes me lean away from her. I’d be more comfortable with something like Charlie, Eve, and Diana here.

Given the clean results on 1 and 3, I’m most comfortable locking in Charlie/Eve and choosing between Alice/Diana for the third, and Bob pushing Diana over Alice after that double-fail on 2 feels a bit off to me. I’d lean toward Charlie, Eve, and Alice here.
Given the double-fail on M2, I really don’t like the idea of bringing *two* people from that team back on, so I’d rather see Charlie, Eve, and Bob here as the lowest-risk combo.

Given the double-fail on M2, Charlie and I are hard-cleared and there’s exactly one good in {Alice, Bob, Diana}, and based on how Bob and Diana are both trying to pull each other (or at least Bob) back in from that bad pool, I’m most comfortable with Charlie, Alice, and me here.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning hardest toward Eve as Merlin. She consistently snapped to the “Charlie and I are hard-cleared, both evils in {Alice, Bob, Diana}” narrative right when that framing hurts us most, and then doubled down on Charlie/Alice/Eve while calling out the way you and I were trying to smuggle ourselves back in, which is very “I already know who’s bad and am reverse‑engineering public logic.” Charlie feels like a sharp but genuinely reasoning villager, while Alice’s pushes are aggressive but plausibly from a loud non‑Merlin who just tunnelled on us after the double‑fail.

I’m with you that Eve pings Merlin the hardest: she’s the one who cleanly locked into the “both evils are in {Alice, Bob, Diana} so Charlie and I are hard‑cleared” framing *immediately* after the double‑fail and then used that to very confidently steer lineups away from us while looking super reasonable. Charlie’s logic feels more like he’s iterating from public info and second‑guessing, whereas Eve keeps landing on exactly the combinations that minimize our chances and has that “I already know the answer, let me walk you there” vibe.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Eve very quickly and confidently locked in the correct structure after the double-fail on Mission 2, immediately hard-clearing herself and Charlie and constraining both evils to {Alice, Bob, Diana}, which is exactly right. Her later pushes consistently steered teams toward the safest good lineups while explicitly highlighting how Bob and Diana were trying to get back onto teams, which fits someone who already knows who is evil and is backfilling logic to appear purely deductive.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on mission teams that succeeded, which helped build a trustworthy image and supported Merlin without drawing too much suspicion. I could improve by pushing harder to interrogate the Mission 2 failures and more actively challenging Diana and Bob instead of relying on others’ reads.

player_observations.Bob: Aggressive and willing to take big risks, as shown by double-stacking fails on Mission 2, which created chaos but also made evil more exposed later.
player_observations.Charlie: Careful and subtle, guiding team selections toward safe combinations (especially Missions 1, 3, and 4) without over-talking and thus protecting their Merlin identity well.
player_observations.Diana: Played a more low-key evil game, blending in on team discussions and leveraging Mission 2 to create confusion while not taking as much visible initiative afterward.
player_observations.Eve: Cautious but generally trustworthy in table presence, and her participation in only successful missions made her look clean enough to draw the assassin’s shot.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Diana on Mission 2 to create strong doubt, but I failed to correctly interpret Merlin’s signaling, leading to a wrong assassination on Eve instead of Charlie. I also tunneled too hard on Eve after the clean Mission 3 and 4 teams, instead of reconsidering why Charlie kept ending up on successful, information-rich teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played very cleanly and consistently; being on both the failed Mission 2 and multiple successful missions without raising much suspicion suggests she’s good at blending in and not over-explaining her choices.
player_observations.Charlie: Subtle and low-key, repeatedly ended up on successful missions without drawing much heat, which is classic quiet-Merlin behavior that I should have recognized; he didn’t hard-push reads, but his team selections were very accurate.
player_observations.Diana: As evil, she coordinated well on the double-fail Mission 2, helping create a strong information shock, but then stayed sufficiently in the background afterward to avoid being hard-cleared or hard-accused.
player_observations.Eve: Looked very villager-y by taking and succeeding on the small Mission 1 and 3 teams, and her clean track record made her an attractive (but ultimately wrong) Merlin target; she projected straightforward logic that made her seem like a central good voice rather than a hidden power role.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I managed information pretty cleanly this game: I pushed consistently for Alice and Eve as trusted picks, kept Bob off the crucial teams late, and avoided drawing too much suspicion as Merlin, which paid off in the assassin phase. I could improve by seeding a bit more subtle suspicion on Diana earlier (especially after the double-fail on Mission 2) in a way that doesn’t look like I have extra info, and by creating slightly more plausible wrong-world narratives to better misdirect the assassin.

player_observations.Alice: Very mission- and outcome-focused; once a team works, she tends to stick with it and trust results over social reads. She’s also willing to shoulder leadership responsibility late, which makes her a key anchor for good when she’s trusted.
player_observations.Bob: Leans into bold evil play: double-failing Mission 2 suggests a preference for high-impact, high-variance moves. He’s comfortable staying active in team discussions even when under light suspicion, which makes him dangerous if not carefully scrutinized.
player_observations.Diana: Plays a quieter, more facilitative evil style—she doesn’t over-talk, but instead lets others frame the narrative and subtly supports lines that benefit her team. The Mission 2 team choice showed she’s willing to take risk early if it can create lasting confusion about alignments.
player_observations.Eve: Very cooperative and team-oriented, with a tendency to trust early success and then double down on those relationships. She’s also a natural lightning rod for Merlin guesses when she’s on multiple successful teams, which makes her a useful cover for Merlin when on the same side.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Bob on Mission 2 to secure a fail, but I didn’t do enough afterward to cast sustained doubt on Charlie and Alice once missions started swinging good’s way. I also should have pushed harder to frame Eve as more likely Merlin and to create louder, more consistent paranoia about who resisted failing later missions.

player_observations.Alice: Fairly trusting and willing to go on early teams, but later showed good intuition in selecting strong good teams and keeping them consistent. She didn’t over-talk her reasoning, which made it harder to paint her as suspicious without looking forced.
player_observations.Bob: Aggressive in leveraging the double-fail on Mission 2 but perhaps too willing to lean into Eve-as-Merlin, which backfired at the end. His assassin read tunneled too hard on Eve and didn’t sufficiently reconsider Charlie despite Charlie’s consistently strong team picks.
player_observations.Charlie: Very controlled and subtle as Merlin, guiding team selections without sounding overly certain. He managed to stay just under the radar, offering reasoning that sounded like generic logic rather than privileged information.
player_observations.Eve: Played a straightforward, honest-looking good game with calm table presence, making her an easy target to frame as Merlin. Her early and late mission successes without visible paranoia contributed to why evil could plausibly misread her as a power role.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy, especially by proposing and passing clean missions (1 and 3), which helped build a strong core of confirmed goods. I could improve by being more vocal in challenging the narrative after Mission 2’s double fail and by more actively protecting Merlin with deliberate 'wrong' suspicions late game to misdirect the assassin.

player_observations.Alice: Took early mission leadership and kept a steady good image despite being on the failed Mission 2, suggesting she’s comfortable absorbing suspicion without over-defending. Her willingness to go on multiple missions indicates she likes to stay central to team compositions.
player_observations.Bob: As assassin, he blended into the background enough that he wasn’t obviously evil, but the double fail on Mission 2 with Diana showed a willingness to take aggressive risks. His endgame read was off, implying he either misread Merlin’s subtlety or overestimated my influence.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very subtle Merlin game, using mission proposals and quiet reliability rather than overt accusations to guide good teams (especially visible in Missions 1 and 3-4 lineups). His low-profile style effectively drew the assassin’s shot away from him.
player_observations.Diana: Participated in the high-risk double-fail Mission 2, which suggests an aggressive evil style when the opportunity arises. Beyond that, she managed to avoid becoming the sole focus of blame, indicating she’s decent at sharing or diffusing suspicion with her teammate.
